introduction.small: On the west coast of the island, this five-star hotel lies in a cove of coral sand.

paragraphs.text:
Long Bay serves as the setting for La Samanna, a veritable paradise that opens onto the ocean. Rendezvous of jetsetters and royals, this grand hotel has 83 rooms and suites, as well as eight villas - completely renovated by London's Muza Lab studios - hidden amongst lush gardens or along the most beautiful beach in Saint Martin.

There are 16 accommodation categories - from romantic rooms to cottages with private terraces - all with a sea view. There is no bling here - the decoration draws its inspiration from tropical style with dark and light wood furnishings taking centre stage. Similarly, fabrics showcase the natural colours found on the island, with subtle shades of blue, green, pink and peach.

The hotel's charm comes from this eclecticism. As expected, the service in the hotel and on the beautiful Long Bay private beach is impeccable. At the indoor/outdoor spa, meanwhile, expert therapists and masseurs do their utmost to make your stay a restful, rejuvenating experience. And at sunset, when the sky is dressed in orange shades and the sand is burnished gold, La Samanna becomes magical.

introduction.small: Just steps away from Grand Case Beach, L'Esplanade offers a luxurious retreat in one of its cosy rooms. Dare to escape your everyday life!

paragraphs.text:
From your private stone balcony, overlook the clear waters of a gentle sea. Nestled among the hill's tropical gardens, be lulled by the peaceful movement of the waves and enjoy an exquisitely tranquil oasis where you can see everything, and yet stay hidden from prying eyes. Your only mission? Relax. The hotel's dedicated staff takes care of everything else you might want, with absolute discretion.
Saint Martin's real secret treasure, L'Esplanade hotel is considered one of the best in the Caribbean. Behind its magnificent Mediterranean facade, a large canopy bed awaits you, and between Spanish mosaics, Mexican tiles and Moroccan lanterns, the immense pool invites you to cool off. In the evening, the sun plunges into the turquoise Caribbean waters and projects a unique light to create a truly fascinating sight.

content.title: Hôtel La Plantation, the good life

introduction.small: Just 500m from Orient Bay and overlooking the tiny island of Tintamarre, Hôtel La Plantation offers guests a truly relaxing stay in idyllic surroundings.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Hôtel La Plantation, the good life

paragraphs.text:
Smell the salty sea air as you open your eyes in the morning, then head to the balcony to gaze out at gorgeous panoramic views of a white sandy beach, lapped by turquoise waters and cradled by a coral reef: it is a simple premise, but effective, and it awaits you at La Plantation. Just five minutes' walk from Orient Bay, the hotel is surrounded by five hectares of tropical gardens, full of palm trees, banana trees, bougainvilliers, hibiscus and allamanda.

The 53 rooms and suites are simple yet vibrant, and occupy 17 single-storey, shingle-roofed villas. Each is home to one suite and two studio apartments that can either be rented separately or together, making this an ideal place for holidays with family or friends. The villas' huge terraces are caressed by the island's trade winds, and enjoy panoramic views over the bay and the marine reserve's neighbouring islets.

After breakfast, either poolside or surrounded by lush green gardens under the pergola, it is time to decide how to spend your day. There is no shortage of options: be it relaxing, enjoying a walk on the beach, or exploring Tintamarre island, a sanctuary for local wildlife and home to iguanas, sea turtles and tortoises, the choice is yours!

Hôtel La Plantation
C5 Orient Bay
97150 Saint-Martin

Tel : +590 (0)5 90 29 58 00

Rooms: from 161 EUR

content.title: Climbing Pic Paradis, Saint Martin's highest point

introduction.small: At an altitude of 424m, Pic Paradis towers over all the surrounding mountains in the ridgeline that runs from one end of Saint Martin to the other.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Climbing Pic Paradis, Saint Martin's highest point

paragraphs.text:
It is one of the only accessible places in the centre of the island. Surrounded by a lush tropical forest, Pic Paradis (or "Paradise Peak") dominates Saint Martin with at an altitude of 424 m. To reach its summit, it takes about three hours to hike from the bottom of the peak - the waymarked path starts close to the Loterie Farm. Along your pilgrimage, observe the iguanas, butterflies and monkeys hiding in the midst of the vegetation. Among this lush flora, the path can sometimes be steep. Nevertheless, it remains accessible even to the youngest, who will be delighted to catch a glimpse of the mountain sheep. Make sure you bring plenty of water or opt for an early morning ascent as the sun can be overwhelming from midday. When you reach your destination, spread the tall wild grasses to discover an unobstructed view of Marigot, Orient Bay, the Caribbean Sea, and much more. If you squint your eyes, you will even see the island of Saint-Barthélemy in the distance!

Pic Paradis
97150 Saint-Martin

https://www.st-martin.org/us/enjoy/must-see-must-do/at-the-top-of-paradise

content.title: La Cigale, French gastronomy on the water

introduction.small: On Lagoon Beach in Saint Martin, La Cigale offers chic and traditional French cuisine facing the ocean, under the shade of coconut palms.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: La Cigale, French gastronomy on the water

paragraphs.text:
Beautifully set on the white sand of the lagoon beach, along Nettle Bay, this family restaurant in Saint Martin, which takes its name from the famous La Fontaine fable of the Grasshopper and the Ant (La Cigale and La Fourmi), is a must for visitors looking for a romantic evening. In an idyllic setting, facing the setting sun on the horizon, the dedicated team will introduce you to a gourmet cuisine with a blend of different flavours.

Here, the plates hark back at the Provence region, the Basque Country and the Massif Central. Snails au gratin with Bleu d'Auvergne blue cheese as a starter, duck parmentier confit with porcini mushrooms and poultry jus with cognac or sole meunière as a main course, an impressive macaron with fresh raspberries and vanilla cream to finish on a sweet note... La Cigale certainly proudly represents traditional French gastronomy and reinvents the concept of the chic restaurant with its feet in the sand!

La Cigale

content.title: Le Piment, French and Italian flavours in the Caribbean

introduction.small: Forget about Saint Martin's specialities and opt for dinner at Le Piment and let your palate wander between French Provence and Italy.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Le Piment, French and Italian flavours in the Caribbean

paragraphs.text:
On the village square in Saint Martin's Orient Bay, the terrace of Le Piment restaurant invites you over with dishes more reminiscent of the typical scents of Provence or Tuscany than those of the Caribbean. You will not find a local speciality here, as the chef draws inspiration for his creations from both the culinary traditions of southern France and Italy. On the menu, start with French antipasti, such as the chausson de Saint-Marcellin cheese pastries, or the toast with pan-fried foie gras. It is difficult to make a choice as the menu is so long: depending on your mood, whether you are feeling more French or Italian, choose the fillet of beef with camembert or the risotto with prawns, scallops and chorizo. Unless you are tempted by a pizza instead, for example the famous "Prosciutto", which is a combination of prosciutto ham – a speciality of the province of Parma – Parmesan cheese, basil and black olives. Reservation is highly recommended.

Le Piment

content.title: Sunset Café, the place to be seen

introduction.small: A completely unmissable venue and a great place to watch the sunset over Grand-Case and Creole Rock.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Sunset Café, the place to be seen

paragraphs.text:
The sunset ceremony is sacred on Saint Martin. Not with your feet in the water but just above, on a pretty all-wood terrace held up by stilts on a rocky mountainside with stunning views of the Caribbean. The Sunset Café is the ideal spot to watch the sun disappear while sipping a cocktail in a cosy lounge atmosphere.

Whether you come for breakfast, lunch, cocktails or dinner, the food is always excellent. It is more like fast food than traditional cuisine; a plate of raw, breaded or grilled fish, for example, or perhaps snail fondue, or pork ribs marinated in barbecue sauce.

The cocktails are spectacular: they plunge you directly into the island experience and remind you that you are on holiday. Try the coconut punch, Planter's punch, Cuba Libre, Mojito, or mirto, a traditional drink made from a Caribbean berry, the guavaberry, all to be consumed in moderation, of course... And as soon as the sun disappears, the music takes over!

introduction.small: At the heart of Saint Martin, Marigot's trendy boutiques rub shoulders with the traditional stalls of yesteryear.

paragraphs.text:
The island's French capital, Marigot, is host to a large outdoor market, where the excitement and hospitality of its inhabitants are on display every morning. Located on the harbour, it is here that locals pick up their seasonal products, fresh fish, and meat. As for produce, this is all sourced from neighbouring islands as nothing grows on Saint Martin.

You will also find a host of crafts: paintings, sculptures, clothing, and jewellery decorated with Larimers, the rare pale blue stones of Dominican origin that are the pride of the Caribbean. Close by is Fort Saint Louis, the 18th-century building that dominates the city and offers a superb view over the bay. South of the city, Marina Port La Royale and its luxury boutiques attract a wealthy clientele. Close to continuous bustle, you can visit the Saint Martin Museum, telling the story of the island from the time of the very first settlers.

introduction.small: Raise your arms and touch the bellies of planes landing at Princess Juliana Airport.

paragraphs.text:
Surprising but true: Maho Beach, which lies west of Philipsburg - the capital of the Dutch part of the island (known as Sint Maarten) - is a world-famous tourist attraction. And with good reason: lying on a towel, you can watch planes landing at Princess Juliana International Airport just a few metres above your head. A plane spotters' paradise, this beach is one of the few places where you can admire the trajectory of an aircraft from the end of a runway.

Watching the planes above the beach has become such a popular activity that departure and arrival times of different airlines are displayed on a table in the bars, and the Sunset Beach Bar even has an enclosure outside which broadcasts radio communications between pilots and air traffic controllers. Be careful and do not forget to breathe: the engine blast can be seriously exciting!

content.title: Green Cay: a different way to stay in Saint Martin

introduction.small: Beautifully appointed villas, ideally located in a heavenly setting.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Green Cay: a different way to stay in Saint Martin

paragraphs.text:
Situated on the hillside above the famous Orient Bay in the most authentic French part of the island, Green Cay Villas is the solution for those who prefer renting a villa to staying in a hotel. This set of five luxury villas is spread throughout a beautiful tropical garden, each with three large air-conditioned rooms that can accommodate from two to eight people, a fully equipped kitchen, a large and spacious living room and two terraces, not to mention a private pool and a wide deck. Inspired by Caribbean cultures, the refined contemporary decor makes for an ideal place to relax and unwind, lulled by the waves. Most of the villas offer a fabulous view of the sea, the surrounding islands, and Orient Bay, while others hidden in the grounds provide more privacy. For families or lovers, just throw in a few water sports and trips to the nearby shops and restaurants and you have got the perfect setup for a dream trip!

introduction.small: The second largest French village after Marigot is also one of the most picturesque on the island.

paragraphs.text:
Thanks to its colourful wooden cottages and lush green hills, Grand-Case is a most enjoyable and authentic place to visit. This is also where you will find the best local cuisine. Dozens of lolos, traditional variants on greasy spoon cafés, are strung along the main street. These are unpretentious but superb eateries, with food served on picnic tables on paper plates, and the air redolent with the aromas of smoking barbecues.

These open-air stands serve grilled ribs, a specialty of Saint Martin, and chicken, which you eat with your fingers. Each week, Les Mardis de Grand-Case (Grand-Case Tuesdays) are an opportunity for residents and visitors to gather around an event that highlights some of the key features of the island: its culture, local crafts, art, French cuisine, Caribbean flavours, and much more, all served up with a side of jazz and Caribbean bands.

introduction.small: Nestled in the heart of a magnificent tropical forest, the Loterie Farm offers outdoor activities in a relaxed and chic atmosphere.

paragraphs.text:
At the foot of Pic Paradis, the highest point on the island at 424 m above sea level, is a former sugar factory. Built in 1773, all activities ceased in 1855. Today it is a tropical jewel, where plant and animal species are carefully documented and protected.

To discover the indigenous species of the island, take the incredible rope course, suitable for young and old alike.

In the aftermath of hurricane Irma that severely hit Saint Martin and Loterie Farm in 2017, William Welch, the dynamic owner of Tree Lounge, completely renovated the place. No more corrugated iron roofs on the cabins and the restaurant: they have been rebuilt following eco-tourism principles, with cedar tiles, which are harmless and biodegradable, in the event another hurricane strikes. Music resonates once again in this oasis, where you will indulge in delicious cocktails, with your feet dipping in the water while gazing at the exceptional views over Pic Paradis! Imagine a multi-level spring water pool system of more than 500 sqm surrounded by nearly one acre of tropical greenery; all this welcomes you for a moment of pure relaxation and fun.

Loterie Farm

+590 (0)5 90 87 86 16

introduction.small: With 70km of coastline and 37 beaches that are among the most famous in the Caribbean to explore, getting through them all is likely to be an impossible challenge.

paragraphs.text:
Your first essential stop has got to be the magnificent stretch of the sandy Orient Bay facing the Atlantic Ocean on Saint Martin's northeastern coast. There, far from the tranquillity of the Caribbean Sea, giant waves smash against the rocks. Split into two, the beach is nudist for the most part.

After that, why not treat yourself to a stop on the smallest of Saint Martin's 37 beaches, well hidden in a cove and protected from view: Lovers Beach. Locals will confirm that it owes its poetic nickname to its size, so small that it can only accommodate two people at a time, and for just long enough to steal a kiss. Next is Happy Bay, which well deserves its name. With your toes in this stretch of soft, fine white sand, you will likely not want to be anywhere else in the world.

Other marvels await you, especially on the side of Creole Rock near Grand-Case Bay. Here, it is time to don flippers, mask, and snorkel and dive into the warm crystal waters among shoals of butterflyfish. If you are lucky, you might see stingrays and turtles (but if you really want to swim with turtles, it is best to go to the tiny island of Tintamarre, a wonderfully wild and protected site that you will not want to miss).

content.title: A sanctuary for flora and fauna

introduction.small: To better preserve a priceless heritage, a nature reserve was established in 1998 on the northeast part of the island.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: A sanctuary for flora and fauna

paragraphs.text:
Located on the east coast of the island, this nature reserve is a triangle starting from the little village of Anse Marcel, passing east of the island of Tintamarre and ending at the entrance of the Oyster Pond lagoon. A sanctuary of fauna and flora consisting of a marine area of more than 3,000 hectares and a land area of 150 hectares, it includes the islets on the east coast: Pinel, Little Key, Green Cay, and Tintamarre, and the islets of the Baie de l'Embouchure.

The famous Creole Rock, facing Grand Case Bay, is also part of the reserve, as are the reefs within 200m of the coast. Sea turtles, bottlenose dolphins, and humpback whales have made it their favourite area for hunting and breeding. The best time to watch them in action is from January to April.

introduction.small: With its natural environment, Saint Martin is a popular destination for golf enthusiasts.

paragraphs.text:
Practice your swing on Mullet Bay, one of the finest golf courses in the Caribbean. Located along a sandy beach with the same name, on the Dutch side, this 18-hole, par 70 (rating: 68.8, slope 129) course designed by the architect Joseph Lee, provides a challenging game in a tropical environment. As a result, it plays host to a large number of Caribbean competitions.

This 5,303m-long course is surrounded by a lagoon and dotted with palm trees and tropical flowers, and stands out more for the tactical mind and precision playing required for each and every shot than for its sheer size. Bordered by the lagoon and Caribbean Sea, it provides a very pleasant stroll, breathtaking panoramas - and also a serious test for golf lovers given that half the holes have water hazards!

content.title: Maho: the Las Vegas of the Caribbean

introduction.small: Casinos, clubs, bars, and restaurants… In Maho, it's non-stop, all night, so you will always find something to do!

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Maho: the Las Vegas of the Caribbean

paragraphs.text:
Saint Martin certainly has a well-established reputation… Every evening at twilight, the island puts its glad rags on and gets ready to indulge in the rich and diverse array of nightlife options. After the magical show of the last rays of sun, the beach bars, clubs, and discos get ready to provide their customers with a magical and unforgettable experience.

The night can last forever on the Dutch side under the sunlamps of the 15 casinos, with gamblers trying their luck until the first light of dawn. Close to the Princess Juliana International Airport, the Maho district is the little Las Vegas of the Caribbean, with rhinestones and sequins, garish neon lights and music, luxurious casinos and trendy nightclubs - even the shops stay open until 11:00 p.m. This is a neighbourhood where the party is in full swing all year round. Whether you are just dipping your toe into life after dark or you are a habitual night owl, jump straight in – there is something for everyone!

introduction.small: What better than a stroll through the centre of Philipsburg, with its trendy boutiques and typical local houses?

paragraphs.text:
Philipsburg, the capital of the Dutch side of the island, is organised around two main streets: Front Street and Back Street. The majority of tourist shops, however, are on Wathey Square. Throughout the city you will find a mixture of traditional colourful houses, small white churches, and modern luxury hotels. The city is especially worth a visit for its duty-free shops.

Between shopping expeditions, however, you can visit the Sint Maarten Museum. Its collections reflect the culture of the island, and the ruins of Fort Amsterdam, in the southeast, which offers a nice view of the bay.

The zoo and botanical garden, which contain more than 80 animal species, are also worth a visit. A tip: do not leave without a bottle of Guavaberry, produced from the Caribbean fruit of the same name mixed with aged rum and cane sugar. The traditional liqueur of Saint Martin, it is absolutely delicious – enjoy in moderation!

Tourist Office
10 rue du Général de Gaulle - Marigot
97150 Saint-Martin

content.title: Saint Martin seen from the sea

introduction.small: To explore the coastline, it is best to head on an adventure…out to sea

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Saint Martin seen from the sea

paragraphs.text:
Thrills and excitement ahead! Hop aboard a two-seater watercraft - a kind of water scooter - for a special tour to discover the wonderful secrets of the island. To give you an idea, the two-and-a-half-hour journey starts in the calm waters of Simpson Bay Lagoon, where you will learn how to drive the craft yourself while admiring the yachts alongside you. Then you head to Creole Rock, a great snorkelling spot on the nature reserve, passing through Galisbay, Friar's Bay, Happy Bay, and Grand-Case. As you cross the harbour, navigating between the moored yachts and kayaks can be a challenge - and you will be amazed at how unbelievably tiny they look compared to the ocean liners floating alongside...

At this point, you head for Creole Rock (also known here as ‘Rocher Créole'), a snorkelling spot in the region's Nature Reserve, before crossing Galisbay, Friar's Bay, Happy Bay and Grand-Case and enjoying fabulous scenery along the way.

Finally, it is time to sneak along a narrow channel for an entirely unexpected payoff: the view when you hit the sea, halfway between Nettle Bay and Marigot Bay, is quite simply spectacular.

content.title: The lolos: for gently spiced Creole cuisine

introduction.small: To take the pulse of local life, nothing beats stopping in at a lolo for a taste of regional cuisine.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The lolos: for gently spiced Creole cuisine

paragraphs.text:
For lunch, head straight to a lolo, one of the informal barbecue restaurants on the coast in Marigot, or on the beach at Grand Case.

These small wooden huts with valances and verandas date back to the 17th-century slave plantations, but today they are laid-back picnic-style places serving inexpensive and unbelievably tasty food: stuffed crab, fritters, shrimp skewers, grilled pork ribs with barbecue sauce, crab rice, sweet potato cakes, and grilled lobsters picked straight from the tank. Lolos date all the way back to the 17th century, to the shops set up on plantations where slaves' rations were stored, along with goods intended to be kept or sold on.

Little by little, slave dwellings became neighbourhoods, and then towns. The ration shops remained in their place and became small local shops called "lolos". This name came from the word "Lot", the sales unit used in them.

Menu: around 7 EUR
